39141872.review:
I have had a ton of fun with this game, and found it well worth the price I paid. The game is rewarding not only in enjoyment, and aesthetic, but does a great job of keeping the player engaged with in game rewards; like constantly finding new animals to join your riot party, or being given coins as rewards to unlock new, and special abilities for your crowd to perform. Not the least of which is causing the evil cops to fall in love with you, and join your side!

These coin rewards specifically are cleverly held in a soda machine that one of your cutesy little creatures will throw his hard earned money into, and then unlock different tiers of rewards via soda cans. I could honestly sit and watch my little elephant put coins in a soda machine for hours.

The game can be mildy repetitive but not really in a bad way. Every level I’ve played so far has had a mix of the similar, and an added twist. This is especially fun when you don’t realize the new enemy might have a pretty powerful new ability, and he wrecks your crowd. Learn from it, rinse and repeat!

The overall level design is done really well. Finding all of your rioteers within the level can sometimes be a challenge, depending on how you start, or where you go from the beginning. Not having enough, could prevent you from having a riot ability later on in the mission. This can cause you to lose out on even finishing the mission at all. Being mindful of the puzzle mechanic to each level is imperative, if you want to get the best rating. Every stage I have played is really distinct and while the same elements apply to each level I felt like they really did a bang up job of creating a unique experience in each mission.

The difficulty level of this game is actually surprising. It’s not a hard game. But it’s not necessarily easy either. And the trick is...it tricks you into thinking that. I felt like the last 3 missions of the second stage kind of skyrocketed in difficulty in order to set you up for the Boss fight. Its hard to imagine a game with tiny adorable little animals blowing shit up, to be difficult, but it works!


While the initial theme behind the game may be somewhat heavy, and violent, (which I 100% support) I find that the use of a kawaii aesthetic with Electro-pop style music, takes the violent and dark theme, and turns it around into something bright, and even hopeful. The animals are so cute, and even the cops are kind of adorable, right before you pummel them to death. 

I think this game could benefit from some sort of multiplayer option. Be it cops v rioters, PVP, or even a really fun custom level builder in game that you can share with the online community or your friends. I could imagine my own map now and it would be so fun to build one.

In the future I would love if the Anarteam would put out new maps and new animals, possible multiplayer options, or even an entire new game with a new gameplay style. Who knows, what I know is I really love this game. It’s earned a solid 8/10 in my book and I hope this developer gets more recognition for its intensely creative, and unique game

34878278.review:
Anarcute is a game that involves leading critter rioters against the Brainwash Patrol, who have dominated the world and rule through broadcasting propoganda and I guess sleep-signals (hence the sleeping rioters, and the ones who are attached to the side of buildings).  The game has a cute aesthetic based on chibi models, simplified yet interactive backgrounds, and catchy + cute electronica soundtracks.  It involves massing up rioters to gain abilities (which can also be lost if you lose rioters at certain thresholds), some of which you need to traverse, but the game works well in that you can find other routes and means to get through the level with what is given.  New abilities range from improving speed or stomping, to bouncing and endless projectles, as well as ludicrous ones like enamoring cops with cuteness or grabbing buildings and throwing them on your enemies.  Though I see the most usage out of the molotovs one.

While the game itself is short, that is only if you intend to breeze through it without engaging it's ranking system.  Getting S ranks in cities can earn you cosmetics, from kimonos to tuxedos.  Also getting more critters unlocks special gliterry eyed exclusive animals that can only be gained if you gather all the critters of the city they are tied to.  But it takes alot of practice to get those S ranks, especially with how the crowd controls.  A bit wonky, seems to follow an invisible actor of sorts that they use to rally around judging by how they may crowd and circle at some times.  They also seem to be averse to bunching up to walls, so you may have difficulty trying to grab props to throw if they are in corners.  That said, it's not all that hard to get used to and once you get the hang of it the means to avoid danger is much easier than it initially seems, good reflexes help with reactionary stuff like mines and shock towers.

Since this game runs in Unity, it could use a level designer function so people can make levels, and with steam workshop functionality they could effectively give this game more life.  But I can understand if that is off the table considering it's been out for a year.

All in all, it's a good game and I recommend it.  Heck, I even 100% it and I don't typically go for achievements and I did those while I was at it.

31879724.review:
[h1][Description][/h1]
Anarcute is a mix of Pikmin and Katamari that focuses on creating violent riots with adorable human-like animals that fight against evil capitalists that threaten the freedom of us all! It combines a very cute art style that is minimalistic but very effective, almost completely destroyable levels, and a fresh take on crowd-based combat.

[h1][Gameplay][/h1]
Each level starts with just a couple of people but you quickly build up an horde of charming rioters who are then used to fight the corrupt police. There are four different countries to liberate and each of them is divided in five to eight levels and one boss. 

Unlock skills as you grow in numbers and tear down even buildings or collect cars and everything else around you to throw it at the enemy! You collect coins from completing levels to unlock and swap skills outside of missions. Free new animal species and customize your army to your heart’s desire and pick only the animals you are interested in. You can even change their costume if you get an S on every level of a country.

The game can be pretty challenging at times, but you get used to it real quick. Stealth levels for example feel a bit overwhelming at times since you barely have any rioters, but it's manageable after you get the hang of it. Skipping difficult sections is also an option, if you simply don't care about the cosmetic unlocks. The controls and the camera movement feel a bit wacky at times, but it's not too bad.

[h1][Music][/h1]
The soundtrack is definitely one of the strongest, if not the strongest point of this game and it's fitting the theme of the game so well; they just nailed it. Each song is bound to make you smile and feel good, and it even makes you care for these little critters. Especially within the main menu, the music is so awesome that I stayed in there for far longer than I was supposed to.

[url=https://anarcute.bandcamp.com/album/anarcute-soundtrack]Checkout the bandcamp page for a preview![/url]

[h1][Conclusion][/h1]
The game’s length is about 5-10 hours which might be too little for the price asked. I recommend getting it with a discount of under $10 which I feel is just the right price.

Regardless of the price, I recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed Pikmin, Katamari, or just wants to have a good time with a very passionate and cute little game.

31867234.review:
[h1]If Rampage and Pikmin had a baby, you’d get Anarcute’s gameplay. Add adorable 3D graphics, a catchy electronic soundtrack, and a host of unlockable skills and animal types and you’ve got Anarcute.[/h1]

Anarcute is one of those games that slipped through the cracks. I have very little to say about it negatively beyond wishing that there was more stages, but I’ll address that in a bit.

The premise of the game is as follows: the world is under the boot of a gas-masked dictator and his riot-geared police force and it's up to /you/ to rally your own forces--never mind that you’re all cutesy, big-eyed critters of the land and sea -- and fight back!

You begin every map with a base group and to fill out your ranks you simply need to walk into other groups of protesters, which can be found on the map. Some will require you to liberate them from cages by smashing “A” or and others can only be accessed by traversing laser and/or minefields. You get a bonus to your rating at the end of a map based on how large your remaining group is, so it would behoove you to take extra care with your riotous cuties.

You also get a bonus for completing your objectives quickly and for beating up the fuzz (haha, get it?)

These objectives includes sabotaging enemy communications, surviving waves of enemies, rallying at predetermined points, and whatever else a good riot committee does nowadays. There are a total of four major cities you’ll rampage through - Tokyo, Paris, Miami, and Reykjavik- and each has its own aesthetic theme and soundtrack. The soundtrack is really, really good. Did I mention that?

Throughout your rampage from node to node on the map, you’ll also see dialogue-less cutscenes during which your masked oppressors will behave nefariously. You’ll also encounter boss fights--one per city--which consist of mechanical giants. Like any good boss, these have attack patterns and stages, during which they’ll change up those patterns. Taking down an entity that big and hulking is satisfying.

After you complete a node, you are graded for your performance and rewarded with a single token. These token can be used on the customization screen to buy powers from the vending machine. There are three tiers of powers, each of which require a certain mob size before you can use them in combat. These powers are a mixture of passive stat increases and special attacks, so find the right combination to suit your play style and sometimes the stage.

There is a bonus to completing each stage with the highest rank (S) so that adds a bit of replayability. There are also different animal types to discover, meaning you’ll need to play stages perfectly or play them twice - once to discover hidden animals and once to get through as quickly as possible - in order to reach 100%

.Pros.
[list][*] A fun mashup of Rampage-esque destruction and Pikmin-esque mob management.
[*] The variety of places to riot through each with their own musical and aesthetic theme.
[*] Cutesy animals… on a warpath. What is there not to like?
[*] Destruction is satisfying.
[*] Levels are quick to playthrough allowing you to tailor the length of your gameplay sessions.
[*] Different powers give you a bit of leeway in how you play.
[*] Buy the soundtrack. Do yourself a favour…[/list]

.Cons.
[list][*] The game is short. Depending on skill level, you can finish it in six hours. Replayability also hinges on skill level
[*]The difficulty spikes at random. The Diamond Tour stage in Miami has frustrated me time and again. Everything else has been very manageable
[*]Gameplay can get repetitive. The stealth stage(s) are a nice touch, but mostly you’ll be destroying targets
[*]The horrifying feeling you get  from seeing those cute little bodies littered on the ground because you weren’t careful enough--you monster[/list]

.Bottom Line.

The game is a blast. It offers a healthy dose of challenge and a fun and hectic atmosphere, though gameplay can become repetitive

If you're a lover of music and cute things, you'll want to check this out. If you're a completionist who likes to get perfect scores and collect all possible collectables, there's something for you as well. If you want to break things and challenge The Man, buckle up and get your riot on.

31795564.review:
This is a good game. This is what you want from a game. There are a lot of games on Steam. A lot of them are alike one another. This is not like them. 

Maybe it's just 'cause this game feels like a good night out on the town with your adorable friends fighting the hostile overlords that operate from the shadows and fund what overtly commercialist dreck millennials sobbingly think passes for musical "art". Maybe this game hits too close to home. Or maybe it's because somebody out there actually knows how to design a game. 

The characters are compelling and believable, and above all, sympathetic and complex. There's no painstaking "trying way too hard" gimmick you get from indie developers or big-name companies to appeal to post-pubescent children. The stylistic choices extend into the very heart of the gameplay's core concept, sending a clear divide between you and them, with no unbelievable 1vs1000 do-everything stubble-chinned antihero. 

The sound's upbeat, bouncy, which on the surface doesn't reflect what you'd expect given the game's overall themes. That's because you rarely get a perspective of hope from this storyline which has undergone all too many tried-and-tired bad ending gamuts in previous media. The song may come off as repetitive, but it's inspiring and defining. 

If there're any flaws, it's that it looks to be too short, like [i]a lot of games coming out these days, cough cough.[/i] You might get a little overwhelmed by all the chaos roaming the street when the marshmallow hits the fan, but this isn't really so much a flaw as what you should expect from mass rioting. 

The controls are wonky. Oh, not with controllers. They're a peach then. Keyboard and mouse are a no-go. Rotating and moving need to be simultaneous which gets awkward with pressing letters. Controllers are your best bet, but there's a hitch. You're stuck with the monopolistic Microsoft Xbox controller everybody seems to fap over despite getting the placement of BAXY backwards and basically feeling like a New Age retro hippie's meditative glassware collection--and almost as heavy, too. Ordinarily you'd rely on x360ce to circumvent this, but somehow things don't go as they do automatically for just about every other game I've ever tried outside of Kero Blaster thus far. You'll get controller input, but then things get strange, which I certainly can't explain. Can you? If so, you'd be doing the human race a favor by sharing with the class. Basically the controls are mismapped--left joystick won't move, right joystick has the axis wrong, and the face buttons do whatever. And if you leave x360ce in the folder, you may lose the function of your trigger buttons when you cave in and use the Xbox controller you picked up at Gamestop because you had company over that one time in a blue moon's tenth anniversary. 

And you will cave in. This game is cheeky and precocious. This game is flavorful and artful. This game is a video game. I've played over two decades of video games, with days upon hours of NES, SNES, Playstation, DS and so forth games under my belt, from back when Final Fantasy was compelling to the golden age of Castlevania which ended with Order of Ecclesia, from Animal Crossing to Smash Bros. Whatcha got there, buddy, if Anarcute's in your library, is a genuine video game. 

You've played angsty marines shooting each other in the head and your 2D fighters with ludicrous button combinations a septillion times before. You've played your tiresomely edgy fantasy RPGs with twelve different flavors of humans and an Argonian, and you've played these things to death. 

You might not be able to handle Anarcute.

31781800.review:
Probably one of the most fun I've had in this type of game. Anarcute is a cuddly little animal game where you go against the establishment and take back your cute world. It's basically a top down shooter/fighter kinda game but you control a whole horde of cute animals on their rampage across the world as they take down a load of cops and helicopters with a load of weird futuristic weapons. There is a very big variety of enemies I have to admit and that definitely keeps it fresh, ontop of that there's loads of different traps all over each level that you have to watch out for. Luckily to help with all that you can pick up a few different enemy weapons which make all the difference, as well as unlockable abilites which you can use as long as you have picked up enough animals in the level so the game really makes you try your best to keep everyone alive.

There are also a bunch of unique and cool bosses that all require different strategies in order to beat them, they are definitely a highlight of the game. The game is kinda short though, took me just over 7 hours to beat all the levels and unlock all the animals, would of probably taken 5 or 6 hours if I didn't bother with extra stuff but I thought why not. Best to get the game on sale if you really want it to be worth it, however if you're a person who likes 100%ing games you'll definitely get a few more hours out of it. There is a bit of trial and error in the game but once you've figured out how everything works its not too hard, some levels can be frustrating at times but never has the game caused me to ragequit and I think that's great, the difficulty of this game is perfect. 

The graphics and overall look of the game is great and really fits with the world and the characters. It's quite cartoony and basic but not too basic, the game could have done with a few more super dark levels (there's only one or two that are almost completely dark aside from a few street lamps and neon signs) because they make the game look a bit more pretty to look at. The sounds are pretty good too, they never get old or annoying. The music is also quite good but I think there should be a few more songs in there, I mean it says there's 22 tracks in the soundtrack but unless all the songs are similar I swear I've heard a bunch of them quite a few times.

On the bad side however the keyboard and mouse controls aren't great, and sure in the game it does say its best played with a controller but I doubt it'd be much better, the main problem is the camera and controlling the animals overall, I've played top down shooters that do it better so I know whats right but it isn't too much of a problem I guess. Aside from that I can't think of any problems I have with it, I mean personally I think there should be more content but that's just me. 

Overall I'd give this game a solid 8/10, if cute animals and beating up cops is what you're into then definitely try this one out.

Play as a variety of cute animals as you rise up against capitalism and take down the oppressive police state! 

At first glance it looks like it would play like Pikmin but instead of ordering your minions around you work together as a group to attack, dodge, and rescue fellow animals, playing as a single unit. Each animal in your riot can pick up environmental items or dropped weapons and throw them and as your riot grows you unlock new abilities which can be the difference between life or death in certain missions. 

There are a number of areas to visit during your rioting rampage and within those locales there is variety in the missions that keep things fresh, where you need to learn new strategies with the increasing diversity of enemies and level hazards. In addition you are scored on each level based on your performance and so there is incentive to replay missions to get the coveted S ranking, as if you do well enough in an area you unlock a special outfit for your rioters (tapirs in kimonos OP)

The music is good and I'm glad I got the soundtrack edition, if you haven't it's definitely worth getting on the side.

Overall I'm very pleased with my anarcute experience and found it was a fun romp with animal friends.

GLANCE RECOMMENDATION: [u][b]76% YES[/b][/u] / 24% NO

[h1]GOOD[/h1]
[list]

[h1]NEUTRAL[/h1]
[list]
[*]The replay value for this game does come in the style of time attacks and S ranking levels which, thankfully, only locks off outfits for your group. I found the rankings to be quite tight and not very fun to gun for, so luckily I was able to unlock all the animal heads by taking my time and exploring the levels.
[/list]

[h1]BAD[/h1]
[list]
[*]It's incredibly easy to lose members of your group in each level, often making you restart the whole level especially if you're after an S rank for those outfits. This would be a bigger negative if it gated off more desirable content, but this does feel like an extra unlockable to gun for rather than something you need to grind your teeth at until you unlock it per world.
[/list]

[h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
A short, cute experience that gives you the replyability should you find the Pikmin-esque gameplay satisfying enough to S rank all levels. It's worth a look if anything for its charming style and excellent soundtrack.

28083946.review:
Anarcute is advertised as a riot simulator. When I think of riots, I do NOT picture the cutest fuzziest animals alive, but there is a shit load of rioting going on.

What’s it about?
You are cute and fuzzy animals that have had it with the government oppression and squishing your desire to spread love. You are so filled with furry rage that you take to the streets and beat the crap out of anyone who gets in your way, taking down every building you can find to combat the evil overlords and bring peace and love back to your world.

You have to navigate your rioters through maze-like levels of buildings to avoid guards, lasers and mines while rescuing your friends to make your group larger. The larger the group, the harder they are to navigate and control. Keeping them from harm is a near impossible task. You move through the level trying to keep as many of your furry friends alive while trying to complete your level objective.

What did I think?
OMG, I LOVE THIS GAME. I have fun even during the most difficult levels. This game stresses me out even less than Flat Kingdom does. You go through different countries, liberating areas and freeing locked-up comrades. You can buy bonuses and earn them. You gain different abilities depending on how many rioters you have in your group. You can get anything: from stomps that throw your enemies, to abilities to knock down buildings and even a roman shield formation to project everyone.

This game is full of adorable visuals, a great soundtrack, a terrifying story line and continued complexity. However, this game isn’t for kids (in my honest opinion). There are snipers and your rioters will die if they take too much damage. I don’t know how well they will react to seeing a bunny sniped in the streets (even if there is no blood). The mechanics of the game continue to impress me and the boss battles are interesting and well thought out. I am also impressed at the animals that you save/unlock throughout the game. They aren’t just your typical animals. They have snails, jellyfish and unicorns alongside the cats, pugs and horses.

Do I recommend it?
This game is by far one of my favorites. I love every aspect of it and I think it’s a steal for $14.99, available on Steam. If you love great music, cute fuzzy characters, a really good laugh and supporting indie developers, then this game is surely for you.

However, if words aren’t enough, please take a look at all the fun I’m having in my [url=https://youtu.be/4IQWSF4-bA4?list=PLFCVXYi4F0A0sE56aWoA5jlnqwRSz12yK] Let’s Play here [/url]

More on www.RealWomenofGaming.com

27910182.review:
The rain falls on the japanese pavement. Its a brand new day under Overlord Lordman; "the one who made gas masks fashionable for everyday wear"
A lone Elephant tucks into his apartment, nodding to other elephants not unlike himself. He gestures to the window; to the world just beyond the thin plate of glass that separates himself and the six other elephants now also inside his home; from the opressed world. They locked his friends up in cages, discluding the tusked ones with him of course, and are all too pleased to beat up whomever for any reason. He looks at the six other tusks in the room. Behind their bright eyes burns a flame unlike any other. The hills echo with the sounds of reckoning. The time has come, for the Overlord, who was oddly fond of towers; to eat many kinds of dirt. They're planning and fears are about to come to a head right now, and right away. The small mob of fellow fellows hit the pavement, and start randomly picking up traffic cones, stalls, cars, and other such; and hop right to it.

This is an army management game where you wake your fellows so they can take in the smell of fire and salesmen. They are a motley crew, but they are all you need to lay claim to the life you once knew once again.

Controls run rather smoothly, but your mob is very floaty. You move forward slightly and your entire ball of adorable animals with scurry headlong into the nearby mine, or what have you. The graphics are good, ways to take on the rank and file police are fairly numerous while, at the same time, remaining pretty straight-forward. The game spells out exactly what you must do, and kinda leaves you to it to do it.

Looks can be deciving, and your army is awful unless you're in a pack.
Tutorial is good and if you follow it, you cannot fail; and that's the problem. You can keep doing the same thing over and over.

Pick up thing; throw thing, stomp them back, pick up thing again unless its a car of course, repeat until they die.

Its super super fun and adorable, but once you find something that works, there is not much stopping you from hardline doing that said thing until you win.

The game rewards exploration through getting new animals, but that's all they are. Decals for your mob. Yeah its neat to see the many colors beat back the police, but its never been something that I never quite tried to achieve.

8/10

26569868.review:
I kinda wanna describe the gameplay as Katamari Damacy meets Pikmin and they get together to overthrow the establishment? Somehow I feel that doesn't really do it justice though?

It's kinda like katamari damacy in that you collect more things (rioters) to be better at breaking stuff and get better powers, but you can lose rioters (your cute creatures in matching t-shirts) which reduces your powers too which makes it kinda like Pikmin, except your rioters dont' have any individual powers on their own that help you solve the puzzle that is the levels.

And I say puzzle, and it's really not right either? I mean I suppose it SORT of is, in that you navigate a city, overcome obstacles with your abilities, beat the stuffing out of the Brainwash Patrol (the mask wearing brainwashed badguys), try to prevent losing rioters (not exactly easy really, in the frantic melees that can occur), and generally cause an adorable little ruckus all over town, breaking buildings, throwing cars, throwing switches, dodging snipers... or any combination of those things.... yes including throwing buildings at one point if you unlock and choose that particular power.

You can find cages filled with rioters that have been captured and usually these will be a new type of rioter that joins you as a result, and sometimes these are hidden. It's pretty easy to find htem though as they're marked on your minimap (and full map), but the puzzle is GETTING to them a lot of the time. The fun mostly comes in how quick it is to blitz through a level and just watch your adorable little malcontents bring down the comically dastardly oppressive dictatorship and liberate countries. Do well enough, and you unlock new outfits to clothe your pugnatious protesting proletariat with.

So that probably neatly describes the gameplay. I suppose you wanna know about the rest of the gubbings? Well here we gooooooooo.

Music: Absolutely amazing, addictive to listen to, charming, adorable, energetic, lots of fun to listen to and well worth the £2 or regional equivalent to buy alongside the game. Perfectly fits the theme, and it's a joy to hear the main theme start up when you begin the game!

Controls: No complaints here! They function well, I've not had any issues, guiding your rioters around can be a little like herding cats, but for the most part they aren't suicidal or overly stupid, and you're usually only likely to lose them when, uh-oh, you gotta go toe to toe with the popo. Targetting your foes is pretty intuitive and whilst I can't seem to find a specific way to change target,  y ou never really need to. just point yourself in the vague direction and go for it. It's pretty intelligent enough to work out you wanna smack seven adorable shades of sweet mary mother of christ out of that gasmask wearing mook barrelling towards you with reckless abandon and their body camera turned off.

Visuals: As the name of the game and the screenshots imply, it's simplistic, and adorable, and deliberately low poly, but it's also surprisingly well detailed. Windows in buildings aren't just painted on, and interiors for each floor do exist. Not highly detailed, but they are rendered and it really adds some extra depth to the visuals. Also there is tons of decoration (and of course as a result, impromptu weapons for use) in the levels, meaning that you are never without something nice to look at (and a handy dandy missile to lob at encroaching oppressors.

Replayability: So far, getting an S rank on every mission, finding all the hidden rioter species, and completing every map are the main reasons to replay levels and go back to earlier zones, and maybe to unlock all the powers you can get from the dispenser. I'm not certain how long this game will keep you engaged, as there's no multiplayer option that I can see, but really, there doesn't need to be, and the asking price isn't gigantic. At just £12 it's not breaking the bank, and it's a good, fun game.

Overall, absolutely recommended, and a joy to play. Go on! Have some fun! Wreck some mind-controlling evil dictator's day!

25289510.review:
Anarcute is an indie rioting game made by Anarteam. In Anarcute you control a riot of animals throguh 4 cities: [spoiler]Tokyo, Paris, Miami and Reykjavik[/spoiler]. This is in a mission to overthrow the evil Brainwash Patrol. The game does ramp up in difficulty at a rather quick rate, which makes this a very challenging game, especially late game. The enemies you face have a good mix of stationary defences (Lasers, tesla towers, mines and gates) and troops (Which range from standard guards to walking lasers and men with wrecking balls).

In Anarcute, you must take your riot and complete objectives in the level which vary from protecting a cart to taking a flag, while so levels have unique objectives [spoiler]such as blowing up the Eiffel tower to stopping a music festival (which I presumed was to boost the morale of the Brainwash Patrol troops)[/spoiler]. Anarcute has a good variety of levels, with a few stealth levels, some standard ones and some with where you must fight waves of enemies. The game's features come in at regular intervals. A good feature of the game is the dispenser, which is a vending machine for power ups. These powers can only be accessed if you have the right amount of people. For example, you can't take down a building with 5 people, but with 30. You purchase power ups, you need to use coins. However, coins can only be collected by completing.

Each city has either a choice of which level(s) to pick or an optional level. However, if you are making a choice, you can do both. This makes the game flow as if you can't do a stealth level, you can try a standard riot. The game also has a good, comedic story. The Brainwash Patrol are in each city, so you must liberate the cities they are in. The story is told in drawn cutscenes. These are mainly told in the form of the news. However, the game has no voice acting, giving you room for imagination. Comedic moments include [spoiler]Blowing up the Moon befriending a shark-fish hybrid to take you across the world's oceans[/spoiler].

Anarcute is very good on the performance front in addition to the gameplay and story. It has a great soundtrack and cartoonish yet detailed graphics. The game sometimes glitches, causing characters to get stuck, but it fine 99% of the time. That is the only issue I have ever had with the game on the technical side.

Summary: Anarcute is a fun, adorable yet well-made riot game worth both your time and its price. 9.5/10

The single player game features four cities unlocked in a linear progression; Anarcute has low replay value as solutions are largely predetermined due to obstructions and it lacks procedurally generated levels. Boss battles are particularly tedious and difficult. Controls are better performed with a gamepad, for which the game was designed. The mob can be moved around, and they automatically pick up objects that can be thrown at adversaries. In addition, nearby enemies can be melee attacked, pushed away, or ran past. Continual attacks lead to super dashes or stomps, while powers are unlocked by increasing the crowd size. Enemies are typically too numerous to attack in a straightforward manner; instead, special abilities must be utilized. Anarcute has a unique premise, but features linear, tedious levels.

24663874.review: Anarcute is kind of like Pikmin, except cuter and more violent, and that's really the only way I know of to describe it. Each level involves building up your horde of cute rioters until they can take on the oppressive government, gaining different group abilities as they grow in number. You can customize which animals appear in your horde if you want nothing but cats or don't like bugs or something, and you can purchase different group skills using coins obtained from completing levels. There are a few stealth levels, and the controls aren't really responsive enough for stealth gameplay, but they aren't particularly difficult and you can bypass them if you want at the expense of not being able to get the 100% completion cosmetics. The soundtrack is extremely good, and probably the best part of the game. It took me around 5 hours to finish the campaign, which I guess might be considered too short to charge $15 for some people, but I enjoyed it enough to think it was worth it.

24655345.review:
Contrairement à d'autres, je n'irai pas jusqu'à crier au génie. Mais ce jeu me semble indéniablement bon, et indiscutablement choupi. On sent qu'il a été fignolé avec amour, peaufiné avec un soin maniaque par des développeurs plutôt inspirés. Du coup, non seulement il fourmille de nombreuses qualités, mais (chose plus rare), il me semble difficile de lui reprocher quoi que ce soit, même en y réfléchissant bien.

Bon, (comme quand on cherche, on finit toujours par trouver), si je devais [b]vraiment[/b] lui adresser une petite remarque, ce serait l'étrange oscillation de sa courbe de difficulté un peu mal dosée... Pas forcément au niveau des boss - parfois c'est juste un niveau qui est bizarrement bien plus "chaud" comparativement à tous les autres qui le jouxtent sur la carte.

Au delà de ce détail - un peu pénible mais pas insurmontable non plus, il me semble qu'il n'y a que de l'excellent travail à saluer!
-Je commencerai par la bande son, vraiment cool, dont certaines mélodies obsédantes et variées restent carrément longtemps dans la tête. Une réussite.
-Le gameplay simplissime, agréable et intuitif, échappe à sa répétitivité en apportant de nouvelles mécaniques au fil des niveaux, généralement sous forme de nouvelles armes à utiliser d'une façon spécifique.
Et le simple fait que [i]"plus la foule est grosse, plus ses capacités évoluent"[/i] fait que l'approche ne sera pas forcément la même d'une partie à l'autre, selon la foule amassée (ou les animaux perdus en route).
-Malgré une relative "imprécision" des déplacements (il s'agit d'une masse "déformable" de bestioles, dont la forme est relative à l'environnement), les contrôles répondent très bien. Tout ce petit monde ramasse bancs, poubelles, pots de fleurs pour les jeter à la tête des méchants, et ils réussissent même à soulever voitures & camions pour les lancer comme explosifs! Un système de lock permet des tirs ajustés sur les ennemis, tandis que la visée "libre" (lancer un truc sur une mine pour la faire péter par exemple) est plus approximative... Mais tout ça fonctionne impeccablement.
-Malgré son thème "révolutionnaire", le jeu parvient à ne jamais sombrer dans le glauque, le violent, ou la propagande politique malvenue. On ne parle pas de "mort", mais de "K.O". Je ne crois pas avoir vu de sang, les sbires du dictateur sont tellement parodiques et rigolos qu'on peut difficilement faire le moindre rapprochement sérieux avec quoi que ce soit de "réel"...
Bref, jouer ces petits agitateurs aux attitudes charmantes ne donne jamais l'impression d'incarner une sale crevure de casseur, même si techniquement, c'est bel et bien ce qu'ils font à longueur de temps. Ici, tout semble être à un énième degré enfantin, dans un univers à l'esthétique aussi colorée qu'attachante, et heureusement très engoncé dans une sympathique innocence.
-Les animaux sont (naturellement) mignons, et c'est un plaisir de s'émerveiller avec niaiserie chaque fois qu'on débloque le moindre renardeau (ou n'importe quel attendrissant bébé bestiole qui fait pousser un "RHOOOOÔÔÔÔÔOOOO" un peu honteux)!
-Pour 15€ et même moins sur les sites de clés, le jeu propose environ 4 mondes composés chacun de 8 niveaux avec un boss de fin assez retors. Il m'a personnellement fallu un peu plus de 11h pour le terminer en délivrant tous les animaux - et pour ceux qui seraient intéressés de finir tous les niveaux en rang "S", ça prendra beaucoup plus de temps je pense...
-J'ajoute que les textes sont dans un français aussi irréprochable que le reste.
Comme tout ça me semble parfaitement honnête, et même empreint d'un talent certain, je cautionne entièrement cette mignonette révolution animalière.
N'hésitez plus, foncez.

[i](Edit: après avoir bouclé le jeu, j'ai fini par dégotter un souci assez pénible, mais apparemment, très peu de gens rencontrent ce problème : un des niveaux - "manga bay" - fait systématiquement (chez moi je précise) planter les drivers de ma carte graphique Nvidia en quelques minutes. J'ai fini par terminer cette map avec les drivers en vrac & les glitchs d'affichage en mode kaléidoskopique. Heureusement, les niveaux suivants s'affichent normalement. Bizarre. J'ai également eu à déplorer 2 ou 3 "fenétrages" irrécupérables qui m'ont obligée à relancer le jeu (sans doute encore lié à un souci de driver graphique). Bien que ce ne soit pas "catastrophique", c'est quand même un peu dommage et gênant, et j'espère que ça sera patché assez vite.)[/i]

설정이 독특하고 귀여운 폭동 액션 퍼즐 게임!!

스크린샷과 동영상을 보시면 아시겠지만 그래픽은 대단한 수준은 아니지만 동물들의 귀여움을 어필하기에는 충분합니다. 다만 시점 조작이 조금 불편한 점이 조금 아쉽네요. 은근히 깨알같은 부분이 많아서 보는 재미가 있습니다. 영상만 귀여운 것이 아니라 노래도 귀여워요.

맵 하나의 클리어 시간, 동물 수, 처치한 경찰 수 중 2개가 S랭크를 받으면 그 맵은 S랭크로 클리어 한 것이 되네요. 시간이 촉박하다 싶으면 동물들을 잘 보호해가면서 경찰들을 모조리 날려버리면 됩니다. 그리고 아무래도 콘솔게임에서 자주 볼법한 게임인지라 그런지 패드가 있는 편이 좋은 것 같습니다.

마지막으로 번역 상태가 그다지 좋은 것은 아닙니다. 그래도 플레이 자체는 어렵지 않지만 좀 아쉽네요. 시바 이누(시바견) 정도는 이해할 수 있는데 토끼를 코끼리라고 이름 붙여놓은 것은 해둔 건 너무한 것 아닌가요! 게다가 게임 들어갈 때에도 "폭동을 일으"... "폭동을 일으키자"도 아니고 글자 수가 잘려 나오는 것이 아쉽네요. 한글화 하면서 이런 부분을 왜 검수를 안 하셨을까. 제작자 분들이 직접 하셨나. 자판기라고 해야하는 것인지 몰라도 "분배자" 메뉴도 어색합니다.

아쉬운 부분이 약간씩은 있는데 그래도 상당히 재밌습니다. 그다지 기대 안 하고 샀는데 매우 만족스럽네요.

24529171.review:
Hace poco que el equipo de Anarteam me dio la clave de su juego, Anarcute, mediante el sitio web Keymailer, y no ha sido hasta ahora que he podido probarlo algo más a fondo.

Tengo que decir, que el juego al principio me hacía bastante gracia pero no esperaba demasiado más allá de unos gráficos bastante monos y un poco de destrucción, sin embargo el juego me ha llevado a todo lo contrario, me ha acabado pareciendo una maravilla.

[h1]Historia[/h1]

El juego tiene un propósito bastante simple. Unas grandes multinacionales se han hecho con el control de varias ciudades importantes y están lavándole el cerebro a la gente para que compren sus productos. El jugador tiene que hacer frente a estas multinacionales a base de protestas, ya sea por las buenas o por las malas hasta acabar echando a estos grupos de las ciudades.

Un pretexto simple que a la vez hace una crítica social bastante interesante, pues pese a estar todo camuflado con maravillosos animales y unos “tipos malos”, el trasfondo es bastante interesante.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Llegamos al núcleo del juego, del cual quiero hablar un poco más. Anarcute se centra bastante en la experiencia jugable, la cual está en constante evolución nivel tras nivel.

Lo primero de todo es que el juego se introducirá con un breve tutorial que nos explicará lo básico y necesario para ejecutar nuestras protestas. Principalmente tendremos que juntarnos con los demás protestantes de la zona y hacer una piña para poder avanzar, ya sea “pacíficamente” en ocasiones, o arrasando con todo a nuestro paso.

Los enemigos serán los soldados de estas multinacionales, los cuales podremos derribar a base de tortas, o bien recogiendo los objetos que hay por el nivel. Nuestro equipo de protesta se hará con vallas, puestos de perritos, sombrillas, cubos e incluso coches para cumplir con el objetivo. Según vayamos avanzando en el juego desbloquearemos nuevos animales y lo más curioso, habilidades.

Sí sí, nuestro grupo de protesta tendrá habilidades y no solo eso, sino que además iremos mejorándolas con unas bebidas especiales que adquiriremos por completar los niveles, haciendo de nuestro grupo lo más especial para la revolución.

En lo que respecta a la duración y las fases, el diseño de cada una está bien cuidado, además de estar todo el juego divido en 4 ciudades diferentes con varias fases cada una, una duración aproximada de 4-5h, aunque si vas con calma y quieres desbloquearlo absolutamente todo nos puede llevar unas cuantas más, por lo que en cuanto a duración está bastante bien.

Hablando en términos generales, tenemos un juego que no para de evolucionar en lo que respecta al gameplay, siempre vamos a tener algo nuevo, ya sean habilidades o enemigos, que nos va a mantener enganchados durante un buen tiempo.

[h1]Aspecto gráfico, sonoro y técnico.[/h1]

Otro de los aspectos más interesantes del juego es el apartado gráfico,  que es un poco estilo low-poly pero con texturas bastante “simples” que en conjunto hacen el aspecto tan mono por el que destaca el juego.

En lo sonoro, tiene un punto bueno y un punto malo. El punto bueno es que la banda sonora es bastante entretenida y en ocasiones cambia bastante dependiendo de la situación, sin embargo se repite mucho la misma pista en el capítulo entero, cosa que puede llegar a cansar un poco.

Respecto a lo técnico, estamos hablando de un juego hecho en Unity, ese “maravilloso” motor que tanto está ayudando a los desarrolladores. Si bien es cierto, que el rendimiento del juego es bueno y no me he topado con ningún bug importante, excepto un nivel en el que no salían los enemigos, sí que he encontrado ciertas “incompatibilidades” con programas de terceros como OBS, donde activar el SSAO puede hacer bajar el rendimiento muchísimo. Quitando eso, el juego por suerte parece que le han dado algunos mimos para que funcione como dios manda.

[h1]Conclusiones[/h1]

Estamos hablando de un título que se sale de lo común y que es perfecto para desconectar. Si lo jugamos con alguien cerca, es todavía más gracioso, ya que todo cuanto veamos nos provocará bastante diversión. Sin duda, es un juego por el que sí merece la pena pagar, ya que seguramente lo disfrutarás.



[b]NOTA: 8/10[/b]

Podéis leer más analisis en mi web: https://blansireviews.wordpress.com/

Os dejo también el livestream que hice del videojuego.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hj_bfxmkhdg

24475603.review:
[h1]Anarcute——非“非暴力”对抗[/h1]

作为手无寸铁的小动物，想要赢装备了各种道具的警察该怎么办呢？人多力量大！先唤醒沉睡的伙伴，每个局部的麻烦，我们都用局部的人数优势快速A死他！把每个坏警察都A死！这就是Anarcute.

整体游戏画面非常可爱，契合主题，音乐的水平也非常高。在这两点基础上，Anarcute把他独特的玩法淋漓尽致的展现出来了。
你有地雷，我们把你的警察跺过去。
你有楼顶狙击手，我们把你楼给拆了。
你有一闪小忍者，我们的翻滚也不是吃素的。
你有激光蜘蛛机器人，我们先把他头拧下来，嗯然后再用你的激光。
你们有流星锤路霸，我们有出租车可以让你爆炸，嗯然后再用你的流星锤。
关键是，以上的你都可以用可爱的小兔子完成！包括打BOSS！
操作简单容易上手，游戏要素引入不紧不慢，升级系统简单易懂又能调整自己的游戏体验，一个游戏同时包含策略，解谜，潜入和一定的动作要素，还很可爱！有什么理由不买呢？

有很多人质疑游戏的价格问题，我觉得以游戏提供的内容来说，价格是可以理解的。关卡数总共只有30关左右，但是游戏刷S评价的空间很充足，想要操作很熟练也需要适应时间，本身的体验也足够优秀。
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
今年的即将推出表里有不少”Riot"游戏。如何在游戏内用一个控制器去操控一个群体？这是做这类游戏很难跨过的一个门槛。曾经有一代经典游戏Lemmings和它的很多后辈，可惜都是横版平台解谜，前有大光头神谷英树身先士卒的Wonderful 101，可惜是3D等角平台游戏，后有大概是游戏性大作Okhlos但是也是以一人为中心的中心式操控，大部分人只是为了视觉效果凑数的。

Anarcute用有限的操作诠释了一下怎么操控一个整体，那就是。。每个人都分开算。每下攻击按键只是随机群体中的一个人执行，而受到攻击的判定也是每个人单独计算。人人平等，没有绝对的英雄，每个人都是英雄嘛。
虽然需要按下的操作数多，但并不至于陷入乱按的局面，通过对道具数量的限制，游戏的策略性有很明显的上升，本来第一大关我还以为这是个坑爹游戏，后来发现。。。
妈的这年头还有这种老老实实不玩三板斧的作者真是。。跪了。
然后发现销量又被我奶暴死了（跪
想通关爽快简单，想拿皮肤，精打细算，没有智障的几颗星星，只有对认真玩的奖励。在下佩服。
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

24404070.review:
눈망울이 초롱초롱한 깜찍한 동물들의 거대한 반란!

동물 캐릭터들이 매우매우 귀엽다. 아닌게 아니라 눈망울이 정말 크고 똘망초롱하다. 뭔 애벌레나 박쥐, 금붕어 같은 캐릭터들도 죄 눈이 똘망초롱해놔서 참 귀여워보인다. 이런 애들이 피켓 들고 자신들의 권리를 외치는 폭도가 된다니... 그리고 폭도라면 보통 RIOT이라는 단어를 쓸텐데, Rio-Cute라고 하면 어감이 이상하다고 느낀건지 비슷한 느낌이 나는 Anarchism에서 게임 제목을 차용해왔다. 어딘가 미묘하지만, 어감이 좋으니 아무래도 괜찮은 것 같다.

각 스테이지마다 뿔뿔이 흩어진 동물 친구들을 규합하여 버려진 물건들이나 장비들을 주워다가 경찰들을 퇴치하고 깃발을 점령해나간다. 되게 아무것도 없어보이는 여린 동물 친구들이 무리를 이뤄 경찰들에게 저항하는 모습이 귀여우면서도 나름 용맹해보인다. 나중에는 미사일이나 빔 같은 것들도 주워다가 사용도 한다. 일부 스테이지들은 아예 유닛 하나로 잠입 비슷한 걸 하기도 하고, 아예 처음부터 다수의 무리를 꾸려 몰려오는 경찰들을 물리치는 스테이지 같은 것도 존재한다. 

그 밖에 각 스테이지를 클리어하고 획득한 코인으로 스킬들을 강화시켜줄 수도 있고, 각 스테이지에 숨겨져 있는 다른 동물 친구들을 구해 동물 컬렉션을 늘릴 수도 있다. 눈망울이 똘망초롱한 친구들이 우리의 도움만을 오매불망 바라고 있으니 가급적이면 전부 찾아서 구해주도록 하자. 진짜 동물들 미칠듯이 귀엽다.

다수의 무리를 운용하는 게임임에도, 생각보다 조작은 편했다. 간단한 조작으로 무리를 쉽게 운용할 수 있도록 제작됐다. 일단 소-중규모(대략 40마리선까지)에서는 조작의 불편함은 크게 못 느낄 것이다. 하지만 다수의 폭도들을 최대한 단순한 방식으로 컨트롤하려다보니 폭도들 숫자가 50을 넘어가면 조작이 조금씩 난감해진다. 다수의 폭도들이 조작대로 순순히 따라오기만 하는게 아니라 중간에 막 걸리고 낑기고 부비적대고 하는 현상이 없을 수가 없다. 게임의 장르와 조작 방식에 따른 근본적인 불편함이라 단점이라고 하긴 뭣하지만, 그래도 불편한 건 어쩔 수 없다.

이걸 제작진에서도 어느 정도 감안했는지, S랭크 클리어 조건이 약간 너그러운 편이다. 처치경찰수, 남은폭도수, 클리어타임 중 두 가지 항목에서만 S를 받으면 해당 스테이지를 S 랭크 클리어로 취급해준다. (사실 처치경찰수/남은폭도수와 클리어타임은 서로 대치되기도 해서 어찌보면 이 쪽이 합리적인 것이지만) 물론 이래도 상기한 조작감때문에 S랭크 획득은 꽤 어려운 편이다. 몇 번 트라이를 해보면서 동선을 숙지해야 한다. 오히려 동선 고민이 필요없는 보스전이 S랭크 받기가 더 쉬울 정도.

요약하자면, 가볍게 즐기기엔 참 좋은 게임이지만, 파고들기에는 좀 어려운 게임이다. 그래도 스테이지가 아주 많은 건 아니고 아주 못할 난이도도 아니라 조작만 조금 감안하면 올스테이지 S랭크도 아주 못할 짓은 아니긴 하다. 게임실력 허접한 나도 했을 정도니.

파고들긴 좀 난해하긴 하지만, 컨셉이 참신하고 동물 폭도들이 너무너무 귀여워서 추천.

24396596.review:
I was gifted this game from a friend quite by surprise and from the moment the game started up I was assaulted with horribly addictive levels of CUTE.

 But I digress, You wanted to know about the game.

 It's highly polished, Everything feels like it fits in, With an overall cell-shaded J-Pop aesthetic that just fits the whole theme of rioters vs "The Establishment". Normally I'm not all too fond of games with that strategy/puzzler feel to it but I found myself repeatedly going back to beat my score if only just to unlock more critters or see more stages.. The abilities are fun and by unlocking different ones in the dispenser as you unlock coins to use in it, You find levels that might have been too hard to get a 'perfect' score in might prove easier to redo. The game does seem a bit unforgiving at times, Where losing ONE guy might drop you just below the tier needed to make it through a level alive or at all eaasily and some levels that have unique objetives such as guiding and guarding a cart through a series of checkpoints frustrated me.

 All in all, I would suggest this game, Especially if you like cuteness and a good challenging strategy game and don't be fooled, There IS strategy. From knowing where to go in any given area in order to maximize your effectiveness, To avoiding police on 'stealth' missions to knowing which abilities to set from the sdispensary.

 Would have liked to see the ability to 'dumb down' or skip particularly hard missions, But overall I'd rate it a 9/10.

24326209.review:
Anarcute is an action game where you’re super cute animals rioting against the evil capitalist. You want to take down the man who has suppressed these cute little animals. The evil must be stopped and we must riot with these adorable animals all the while listening to cute tunes!

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]

As the name suggest the game features highly cute animals with a very cute art-style. The game looks very nice, not the best graphics in the world but it’s not meant to have those realistic sort of graphics anyways. The game looks like it’s made by Nintendo as it features those Nintendo Wii/Gamecube type art-style. The game ran over 100 FPS for me the almost all the time I played. I noticed some dips in FPS, though very rarely. The graphics menu has some customizations like resolution, SSAO, vsync, shadows quality, etc. 

[h1]Sound:[/h1]

Just like the art-style the music is so cheery that It made my day just listening to the tune. Super cute and awesome music. I can listen to those tracks all day long. The audio effects and music have separate adjustable levels.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]

You’re a bunch of cute animal rioters. You start off with a short group of 1-4 animals and throughout the map other rioters are sleeping (I think symbolism?). You just walk next to them and they’ll join your party. Some rioters are trapped in cages and you must break these to have these rioters join you. If you get 10 or more rioters, you get the stomp ability which you can use to push some barriers. These can also be used to knockback enemies. Your animals can attack enemies, throw objects at them, even throw cars at them. Rioters can also knock down buildings once the number of rioters reaches high. You have a level bar indicating how many rioters you have and at certain points on that bar new powers get unlocked. The bigger the rioter crowd, the more powerful you’ll be. You can kill enemies by clicking on them or by throwing cars and other things at them. Stomping also does damage and knocks them back.

You start off in Tokyo and there’s a bunch of levels in it. Then there are 3 other cities like Paris, Miami etc. where you go to cause riots. Naturally, as you progress the missions get harder and harder. Missions include stuff like capture the flags throughout the map or take down certain brainwashing building (reference to media buildings I think), take down statues and structures etc. There are lasers, mines, snipers and many other traps. You must avoid these or you’ll start losing rioters. Once all rioters are dead, it’s game over.

You get coins when you complete levels and you can use these to get upgrades from the dispenser machine. Upgrades include stuff like walking faster, ability to double dash without having a cool down in between etc. You also unlock new animals when you free rioters from cages.

Each countries’ end stage features a boss battle where you have to beat it. These bosses have patterns and you must try to find their weakness and kill them. Once you beat the boss the evil capitalist dictator moves to the next country and that country gets unlocked to play in. All the countries have their own respective theme.

A short gameplay video can be found below:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=724733601

[b][u]Graphics:8/10[/u][/b]
[b][u]Sound:10/10[/u][/b]
[b][u]Gameplay:8/10[/u][/b]
[b][u]Overall:8/10[/u][/b]

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]

You want to wreak havoc with cute animals in large groups? You want to take down the man and be free from their capitalistic ways? Do it with Anarcute! Very fun game and awesome music. Kids especially should enjoy this game and if you’re an adult this game can really cheer you if you’re feeling down.

24323965.review:
I hope this is doing well, it deserves to. It puts my mind in a weird place. Somewhere between quirky Japanese titles like Katamari Damacy, and extremely well-polished shareware games of the '90s. I absolutely adore it. The controls are honed to perfection (especially the auto-aim mode, which I wish was the default for keyboard & mouse), the gameplay is genuinely fun and unencumbered, and it's just all very silly.

It's also very typically French, which is beautiful. It has that... air about it. It's like how Britain is obsessed with monolithic super-governments, nanny states that think for you and control people. That's come up in so many of our shows and games, from Blake's 7 to the upcoming We Happy Few.

Anarcute is like that but more relevant to French culture and the concept of Anarchism and the revolution. So there's definitely something intelligent there behind all the colourful characters and the friendly, cartoony visuals.

I don't know. It's hard to explain. It feels fun to play. Not fun in a 'mobile game' sense (I'm not a fan of mobile game design), but fun in a sense that video games were in the '90s and early '00s. It's like a love-letter to that era but with more modern considerations regarding the gameplay. Only slightly more modern, though, really. The UI is really bright and vibrant, and getting an S rank on everything is actually really difficult!

But there's something more modern about it that really makes it sit well in ways that sometimes playing games from the '90s doesn't always. It's a perfect fusion. And it's something that I really wish I'd see pop up more often. If Ori & the Blind Forest is a pure Castlevania but modernised to just the right amount. This is that for Pikmin or Katamari Damacy.

It's brilliant!

24316685.review:
[h1]This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer/publisher but this did not affect my opinion on the game.[/h1]

Anarcute is an action game developed by a group of five French students; Anarteam, and published by Plug in Digital, releasing on PC and Xbox One in July 2016. 

I was absolutely in love with this title right from launching it. The gameplay is simple yet has a keen eye for depth and just the right amount of difficulty. The aim is to roam around the world you are in, freeing captured companions who will join you in the game’s main aim, to cause anarchy and riots. It took me a while to get the pun in the title, but its Anarchy, and cute combined, because have you seen these animals?! Cute as a button!!  Back to the gameplay; the rioters which join your party will raise your threat level, allowing you to use your special abilities. The more rioters you have in your party the more threatening your group is. I particularly like the ability to knock down buildings to save potentially captured companions which are precariously stuck on the side of it! The missions that you carry out take place in various different countries around the world, but the idea is still the same regardless.  The combat is simple; you just hover your mouse around the general area of an enemy and your rioters will wreck them (or not?) depending on how much you outnumber them. 

Whilst Anarcute may not look the most graphically impressive style game, but it just screams character. It looks just like a game from Nintendo and I love it! The cute animal companions you find scattered around the world are so cute. All of the character models are nicely designed as well as some nice smooth animations across the board. The soundtrack is completely on point as well, with some top of the range sound effects too. 

The difficulty does increase as you would expect as you progress further into the game; but you can negate a little bit of this buy purchasing upgrades for your squad of rioters which will assist you such as being able to run on infinite amount of ammo and projectiles bouncing between enemies more often. Some levels will also require retrying multiple times in order to find the best route throughout it without losing half your squad to silly mistakes. 

The game won’t take a huge amount of time to complete, there are 4 or 5 countries to fight in, and each country has about 10 levels in each, and these levels will have different objectives which can range from capturing flags, or playing a mission completely solo and having to avoid enemies line of sights. This game however screams for a co-op/multiplayer mode, it would just add a whole new level of content and replayability, hopefully the developers will find time to add it in a future patch. 

I was a little disappointed to find that even though the game suggests at the start, that you use a controller, but I couldn’t get mine to work, this was with two separate xbox controllers, whilst the game is playable with mouse and keyboard, I can’t help but wonder how much easier the experience would have been if I got to use the prefered controller option. 

Overall Anarcute is a hugely fun game to play, it was more fun than what I expected and I was expecting a lot just from the screenshots and info which was available. The cute character models and soundtrack are awesome, and fit perfectly well into the game’s addictive gameplay.

24315996.review:
[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I] A good game for kids and newbies to the action strategy genre [/i]

[b] Summary: [/b]  Anarcute is one of those games you can sit back and relax with, as you cause destruction of your own cities and overthrow the brainwash police. With a nice soundtrack and some great initial gameplay, you'll run around causing havoc with a goofy smile on your face. But then the game gets into a groove that turns into its main problem overall. When the game does change the pace, it does it rather well, with stealth sections or bomb escorts that force you to play a little differently. But it doesn't do it often enough, as you are forced in yet in what seems yet another level that you feel like you've played before. And while it can punish you for being reckless, the game's difficulty is really where the game doesn't deliver for veterans of the action strategy genre. For those looking for their first experience in the genre or looking for a game for kids, Anarcute does a great job as an introductory game in the genre. It just doesn't have the mechanics to keep you interested if you've played games like it in the past, and the KISS principle only goes so far. For me, it's a target sale title, as it has a relaxing feel to it. Well, as relaxing as anarchy can be.


[b]Video Review: [/b] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_QDLBJcKm3A

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*] The artwork is lovely. The use of color not only is appealing, but it's able to do it for the most part without interfering with gameplay whatsoever. Child-like, but with a draw for all ages.
[*] The cutscenes do a great job of presenting story without having to say a word. Love the presentation here, it's just fun to watch.
[*] Has that goofy fun factor that brings a smile to the face. It's always fun to just swarm an enemy and take them down. 
[*] Teaching mechanics early in levels work rather well in problem solving. This is done specifically by forcing the player to choose the best path to get as many rioters as possible while facing minimal resistance. 
[*] The game is ridiculous in the right ways, creating that feeling of “wait, what?” while still working within the world created here. 
[*] Game does punish recklessness in terms of charging in without any sort of restraint. Forces you to pay attention to its environment. 
[*] The crab boss battle. One of best challenges in the game and a bunch of fun....as soon as you figure out how it works. 
[*] Music is upbeat and does the job. Catchy. 
[*] When the game does do a change of pace, like asking you to do a stealth section, it works rather well in offering a new challenge (but see the negatives for the counter to that!)
[/list]

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list]
[*] Too easy. While the game does have some more difficult sections, when getting enough rioters, things become way too easy. Granted, there is a score chasing mechanic, but it just doesn't do enough to overshadow the feeling that you're breezing through the game.
[*] There's hiccups in the performance here. You'll notice it every so often, with 5-10 fps drops. Even when recording I saw it, and the big issue in my mind here is that there's seemingly no easily identifiable cause for it. It just seems random. 
[*] The games variety will need a shot in the arm at certain points. There is variety in enemies and levels in the game, but the rate of implementation is where the big problem here is, as there are sections that you are desperately needing something new to mix things up. It's about the overall pace here.
[*] The game doesn't do a good job of teaching some of its mechanics, and forces you to figure it out without giving you a good set of clues in order to do it.
[*] If you plan on playing with a keyboard and mouse: don't. The controls “work”, but compared to the controller, it's inferior. Camera controls in particular are the issue here. It just works so much better with a control stick. 
[*] Something the sound design just is off here. There's sound in appropriate places, but I can't help but be underwhelmed by what's implemented. Turning off the sound didn't have an effect AT ALL in combat, which usually indicates to me that it doesn't do a good job of complementing/helping the player. 
[*] Bosses in general are underwhelming. They rely on specific mechanics that just don't fit here.
[*] I never saw the use of the super dodge. Your main dodge is too useful, and given the compact spaces for battle most of the time, super dodge just doesn't really serve a purpose.
[*] If you're looking for the reason why you're rioting, you're in the wrong place. Game doesn't really do a good job of telling you what caused the riots in question.
[*] Certain mechanics in the level design end up clashing with each other. In particular with very tight corridors, as not know which of your entourage is actually going to throw an item can make lining up a shot very difficult. 
[/list]

This is one of the few games I have ever binge played, and I love it.  I may be biased because I adore the concept of small cute animals running around, wreaking havoc around them, but I really just honestly enjoy playing it.  The only complaint I have with it are the sometimes finnicky controls and feel of the crowd once it grows huge, and especially when you're trying to perfect stages.  I think it may be on part of my rustiness as well, for as I keep playing I'm managing to predict how situations will work out.  I managed to achieve victory of the main game through incompetence fairly easily within five hours, but stopped before the post game to go back and begin getting S rank in all the earlier levels, and the jump from just kinda haphazardly blowing the level's face off to actually putting the effort into completing the levels with any sort of respectable score is definitely a significant one. TL;DR 9/10  Came for the concept, stayed for the gameplay.

One of the best cute games I've played in a while.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hnUIP_KqWlk

To start off, I've been wanting to play this game for months and I'd even contacted the dev as soon as I saw this in upcoming releases, back in January. They gave me the key yesterday and I decided to play it as soon as I could and I wasn't disappointed. I know from the email response I got back that these indie devs do not want to sell a broken or incomplete game, unlike many other devs do these days. I've finished the Tokyo levels already and as far as I've come this game feels like it's one of the best cute games of 2016 so far, the other one that I know of and have played being Paws: A Shelter 2 game.

It's very rare to find a gem like this and as a Youtuber these games make my life a lot easier. Every day I have to go through numerous websites and mile long lists to find games that wish they were like this one. I get keys for many games and I usually do enjoy all of them but it might also be the anticipation that's making me so crazy about this particular game. I love when devs pay attention to the emails that Youtubers send to them, this means that even their social/advertizing department is excellent.

Now for the game. The style is adorable, there are many characters that you can (and will want to) unlock. The artwork, buildings, layout and boss fights are amazing. I had a lot of fun playing this game and I'm [b]really[/b] looking forward to playing again.

Plus, trading cards and achievements. This game is the whole package for a reasonable price. Get it while it's on sale so you can save yourself a buck or two.
